required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Oslo Stan vs Lactate Observational Study
clinical_study.official_title: The Oslo Stan vs Lactate Observational Study, an Observational Study Were we Compare the Clinical Performance of Two Adjunctive Methods to CTG in Intrapartum Fetal Monitoring

brief_summary.textblock: The main aim of the study is to compare the clinical performance of two adjunctive methods to CTG in intrapartum fetal monitoring: FBS with measurement of scalp lactate and ST analysis of the fetal ECG.

detailed_description.textblock:
We use Lactate as a standard adjunctive method in our hospital but we have STAN software available ( is demasked) in our CTG monitors. We will include all women in labour with an intern scalp monitoring and analyse the CTG, the lactate samples and the STAN signals in the same patient and
- Study the relationship between the decision-to-delivery interval and neonatal morbidity in deliveries monitored by scalp lactate measurement
- Compare the diagnostic capability of both methods to identify fetuses at risk of hypoxia
- Compare the false negative alerts from both methods
- Explore the temporal and quantitative relation between fetal lactate metabolism and ST interval changes of the fetal ECG

primary_outcome.measure: Is fetal hypoxia (defined as arterial umbilical cord pH < 7,1 postpartum) superiorly identified by fetal scalp blood sampling (lactate) or ST analysis of fetal ECG
primary_outcome.description: Compare the diagnostic capability of both methods to identify fetuses at risk of hypoxia (i.e.umbilical artery blood pH ≤7.1) Compare FBS lactate with STAN in order to identify the superior method to avoid cord-blood acidosis at birth (i.e.umbilical artery blood pH >7.1) Compare the true negative alerts from both methods, specificity

primary_outcome.measure: Is cord blood acidosis, measured as pH in the umbilical artery postpartum affected by the "Decision-to-delivery interval" measured in minutes from Lactate warning until delivery.
primary_outcome.description: To assess the effect of increasing time interval from the objective warning of intrapartum fetal hypoxia with fetal scalp lactate ≥ 4.8mmol/l to the end of operative delivery on the percentage of moderate cord-blood acidosis at birth (i.e., umbilical artery blood pH ≤ 7.1)

arm_group.arm_group_label: Fetus in labour at risk of acedimia
arm_group.description: The Group of patients studied are fetuses in labour at risk of hypoxia with internal fetal monitoring and scalp lactate bloodsamples ( standard monitoring).

arm_group.arm_group_label: Fetus in labour at risk of acedemia with STAN analysis
arm_group.description: Same group of fetuses in labour at risk of hypoxia with internal fetal monitoring and STAN analysis(ST waveform analysis of the fetal electrocardiogram, opened after study inclusion finished)

intervention.intervention_name: STAN ( St wave analysis) and fetal blood sample-lactate
intervention.description: The CTG will be analysed by an expert group additional to the standard procedure that have been done in Labour already. The STAN analysis will be decrypted/ demasked anonymously by the Company producing these machines.
intervention.arm_group_label: Fetus in labour at risk of acedemia with STAN analysis
Fetus in labour at risk of acedimia

study_pop.textblock:
Women in labour who are monitored with CTG and FBS with measurement of scalp lactate. CTG monitoring in the study is achieved by an internal spiral scalp electrode combined with a pressure-sensitive external contraction transducer. FBS is performed at the decision of the attending obstetrician. Capillary blood is obtained from the fetal head via a stab wound and analyzed with a bed-side test (Lactate Pro). The monitoring procedures described above are identical with the current clinical routine at the department.
The department utilizes S31 fetal monitors (Neoventa Medical AB©, Sweden), which are equipped with the hard and software tool for ST analysis. Once the scalp electrode is attached, ST analysis will be performed and recorded continuously. ST information is blinded throughout labor, i.e. clinical management will only be based on CTG and FBS if indicated. No additional technical equipment is necessary for the project.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Singleton pregnancy
- Cephalic presentation
- Gestational age ≥36+0 weeks at delivery
- Presence of antpartum or intrapartum risk factors for fetal hypoxia according to Norwegian guidelines and therefore indication for electronic fetal monitoring with scalp electrode .
Exclusion Criteria:
- Multiple pregnancies
- Breech presentation
- Gestational age < 36+0 weeks
- Contraindications for placement of a scalp electrode (HIV or HBV or HCV pos)

overall_official.last_name: Jacobsen F Anne Flem, MD, PhD

responsible_party.investigator_title: Senior Consultant, dpt of Obstetrics, Prof II University of Oslo
